conclusion: To determine the coefficient of kinetic friction \( \mu_1 \) between the block and the plate, we need to analyze the forces acting on both the block and the plate during their relative motion.
When the block is placed on the plate, there will be frictional forces acting that will cause the block to accelerate forward while slowing down the plate.
The block has a mass \( m \).
The plate has a mass \( M = 2m \).
The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the plate is \( \mu_1 \).
The coefficient of kinetic friction between the plate and the horizontal surface is \( \mu_2 \).
The block experiences a frictional force \( f_1 = \mu_1 mg \) from the plate.
The acceleration \( a_1 \) of the block can be written as \( a_1 = \frac{f_1}{m} = \mu_1 g \).
The plate experiences a frictional force \( f_1 = \mu_1 mg \) from the block acting backward on the plate.
The plate experiences a frictional force \( f_2 = \mu_2 \cdot 3mg \) from the horizontal surface.
The net force on the plate causes it to decelerate, and its acceleration \( a_2 \) can be written as \( a_2 = \frac{(\mu_1 + 3\mu_2)g}{2} \).
Eventually, the block and the plate reach a common velocity, meaning they have the same acceleration, so \( a_1 = a_2 \).
